awd_titl_txt: CyberCorps Scholarship for Service at the University of Massachusetts Amherst
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal will inaugurate a CyberCorps® Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at the University of Massachusetts (UMass) at Amherst, the Commonwealth?s flagship institution of higher education. This program will support and expand several of the University?s advanced programs that educate and train cybersecurity researchers and professionals. It will support four interdisciplinary cohorts of seven scholars across four nationally-recognized colleges and departments at UMass: computer science, electrical and computer systems engineering, mathematics and statistics, and business. The proposed program has several key objectives. It will create the CyberCorps® community that ensures their success through strong peer-mentoring, faculty advising, and academic and professional support. The program intends a 100% placement in government cybersecurity positions, leveraging the UMass faculty?s many relationships with various federal and state labs and offices. UMass?s academic programs in cybersecurity have and will continue to provide high-quality education and research opportunities, with instruction from and collaboration with leading scholars in the field. Its academic programs will address the multifaceted nature of cybersecurity by continuing to expand and integrating interdisciplinary material. 

The program will prepare students for successful careers in cybersecurity, through a combination of strong curricula, ample professional development, extensive advising, interdisciplinary enrichment, and access to recruiting opportunities. In addition, the program will continue and expand UMass?s existing mechanisms to recruit and retain women and underrepresented minorities into our undergraduate and graduate programs. This program will directly impact the cybersecurity workforce by training 28 cybersecurity professionals. Further, this program directly encourages interdisciplinary work between faculty. More generally, the developments under this program, including curriculum, professional development, broad interdisciplinary collaboration, and recruiting focused on women and underrepresented minorities will provide a broad and sustained base to attract more students into UMass?s cybersecurity programs into the foreseeable future.

por.por_cntn:
The CyberCorps Scholarship for Service at the University of Massachusetts Amherst supported the education and professional development of 34 students across four nationally-recognized UMass colleges and departments: Computer Science, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Mathematics and Statistics, and Management at both the undergraduate and graduate level. We created for SFS students an academic community that ensured their success through strong peer-mentoring, faculty advising, and academic and professional support. We prepared them for successful careers in cybersecurity through a combination of strong curricula, ample professional development, extensive advising, interdisciplinary enrichment, and access to recruiting opportunities.

23 students went on to fulfill their service obligations in qualifying positions; nine are still in the service phase and in qualifying positions; and one is currently seeking a qualifying position. Three additional students began under this award, and will be continued under a subsequent SFS renewal grant. Ten of our students were women, and three were transfers from local community colleges, aligning with our diversity and broader impact goals.

Students fulfilled their service obligations at a broad list of agencies, including National Security Agency (NSA), Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), U.S. Department of Justice, U.S. Air Force, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory (NRL), Naval Surface Warfare Center, National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA), Los Alamos National Lab (LNL), Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), the University of Massachusetts Amherst, MIT Lincoln Lab, and MITRE.

Student completed internships at a similarly broad list of agencies, including National Security Agency (NSA), Department of Homeland Security (DHS), U.S. Air Force Research Lab ACE program and Civilian Services, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory (NRL), Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), Federal Trade Commission, Space and Naval Warfare Systems Command, Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA), Institute for Defense Analysis, the Massachusetts Office of the Attorney General (Digital Evidence Lab), the Rome NY Air Force base ACE program, the Hanscom Air Force base, remote NSF-sponsored internships, and MITRE.

We also engaged in projects with significant synergistic value to SFS. In partnership with the Massachusetts Office of the Attorney General, we have created a year-round on-campus internship program for their Digital Evidence Lab. Several SFS students have interned in this lab, including during summer 2022. We started a new regional workshop "New England Hardware Security Day" which was held for the first time, virtually, in 2021, and in both subsequent years, most recently at Northeastern University in 2023. We planned and executed a summer 2022 event for high-school students at UMass -- held jointly with another NSF awardee -- to learn about computer science. The program was successful and will be run again in summer 2023.

Overall, the main goals of this grant project were met, including our broader goals of strengthening the cybersecurity program at UMass, and diversity and inclusion goals among our applicants.

 


Last Modified: 05/10/2023
Modified by: Brian N Levine
